title: No sync target, waiting for peers

labels.name: P3
labels.description: Medium (ex: JSON-RPC request not working with a specific client library due to loose spec assumtion)

body:
### Description

New node can't sync to existing validators

### Acceptance Criteria
* non-validating / validating node startup issue

### Steps to Reproduce (Bug)
1. Installed Besu (with prerequisites), it runs ok, help command works ok
2. Created static-nodes.json file with known validator enode strings
3. Open port 30303 in my firewall
4. start besu with --network-id, --nat-method, and --p2p-host flag data specified

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
 
   Besu node should start and start syncing nodes from known validators. I will then send my enode data to the existing validators, so they can add my node as a new validator in the network, upon approval.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

```
> besu --network-id="1XXXXXXXXX7" --nat-method="UPNP" --p2p-host="external.server.ip.address"
```

**Frequency:** [What percentage of the time does it occur?]

at startup, startup fails, need help

### Versions (Add all that apply)
* Software version: besu/v1.4.1-dev-ad5bfecd/linux-x86_64/zulu-java-13
* Java version: 

openjdk version "13.0.2" 2020-01-14
OpenJDK Runtime Environment Zulu13.29+9-CA (build 13.0.2+6-MTS)
OpenJDK 64-Bit Server VM Zulu13.29+9-CA (build 13.0.2+6-MTS, mixed mode, sharing)

* OS Name & Version: Linux Mint 17 Qiana (Ubuntu 14.04 based)
* on a dedicated server, not a VPS

### Additional Information

notes:

It seems to be trying to use the server internal NAT address, probably picked up from some sort of ifconfig command maybe?

    Router | Configuration did not create a StreamServer for: //server.internal.LAN.ipaddress

In my setup, I am using NAT translation via an edgerouter to assign IP addresses, so the NAT will not be the same as the external IP address, which I have replaced in the logs with server.internal.LAN.ipaddress and external.server.ip.address, respectively. 

Is there some additional network settings I can use here?

It seems like it's just hanging on this:

    INFO  | FullSyncTargetManager | No sync target, wait for peers.

Why is my node not syncing to the existing validator set and downloading blocks? Help?
I have the same problem.
Will anybody be assigned to this issue? We're having a hard time launching the Government Blockchain Association chain implementation validator nodes because of this blocking issue, right now.

@yehia67 are you having the same problem on the same network or on a named network (i.e. mainnet). Named networks can sometimes take several minutes to find good peers while these logs seem to show Besu was run for only ~3 minutes.
@Tectract we will be looking into this shortly. Hopefully we'll have a fix or workaround sometime next week!

I can see that you are trying to define p2p-host yourself. Could you try to launch Besu in MANUAL mode instead of UPNP ? This should make Besu work while waiting for us to analyze where the problem comes from https://besu.hyperledger.org/en/stable/HowTo/Find-and-Connect/Specifying-NAT/#manual

I can see in your logs `enode: //feXXXXXXXXXX9@external.server.ip.address: 30303` it would seem that your variable `external.server.ip.address` does not contain the IP (or is it a sanitization of your logs?)

@timbeiko  I try to create my own network on aws VPC
The details are here:-

Hello everyone. 
I am trying to create a besu private network using IBFT2 on AWS VPC. I follow this tutorial  https://pegasys.tech/setting-up-hyperledger-besu-in-aws/  
I have 2 instances on private subnets and 2 others on public subnets. One of my private instances is the bootnode. 
I run it using this command  for bootnode 
`besu-1.3.6/bin/besu --data-path=data --genesis-file=./genesis.json --rpc-http-enabled --rpc-http-api=IBFT --rpc-http-host=0.0.0.0 --host-whitelist="*" --rpc-http-cors-origins="all"  --metrics-enabled --metrics-host=0.0.0.0 --metrics-port=9545 --p2p-host=< Private ip> & `     
then I run this command on each instance
` besu-1.3.6/bin/besu  --data-path=data --genesis-file=./genesis.json --node-private-key-file=/opt/besu/keys/key   --bootnodes=enode://<bootnode Public Key>@<bootnode Private IP>:30303 --rpc-http-enabled --rpc-http-host=0.0.0.0 --host-whitelist="*" --rpc-http-api=ETH,NET,IBFT  --rpc-http-cors-origins="all" --metrics-enabled --metrics-host=0.0.0.0 --metrics-port=9545 --p2p-host=<node private ip> &` 

Once all of them run they can't find other peers I don't Know why and It keep giving me this message forever.
`2020-03-26 13:51:55.658+00:00 | EthScheduler-Timer-0 | INFO  | FullSyncTargetManager | No sync target, wait for peers.
2020-03-26 13:52:00.659+00:00 | EthScheduler-Timer-0 | INFO  | FullSyncTargetManager | No sync target, wait for peers.

2020-03-26 13:52:40.665+00:00 | EthScheduler-Timer-0 | INFO  | FullSyncTargetManager | No sync target, wait for peers.
2020-03-26 13:52:45.666+00:00 | EthScheduler-Timer-0 | INFO  | FullSyncTargetManager | No sync target, wait for peers.
2020-03-26 13:52:50.666+00:00 | EthScheduler-Timer-0 | INFO  | FullSyncTargetManager | No sync target, wait for peers.
2020-03-26 13:52:55.667+00:00 | EthScheduler-Timer-0 | INFO  | FullSyncTargetManager | No sync target, wait for peers.
2020-03-26 13:53:00.668+00:00 | EthScheduler-Timer-0 | INFO  | FullSyncTargetManager | No sync target, wait for peers.
2020-03-26 13:53:05.668+00:00 | EthScheduler-Timer-0 | INFO  | FullSyncTargetManager | No sync target, wait for peers.`

Could anyone tell me please what the problem could be? Thanks In Advance.

Yes, I tried both ways, UPNP and MANUAL for nat-method. I will try leaving it runnng longer and report back :) 

Yes, I sanitized the logs, to indicate internal LAN versus external IP, there. I'm not specifying the network, so Im just trying to connect to MAINNET, the default setting there.

I can see that you are using the private ip for the p2p-host --p2p-host=<node private ip>
if your instances are on different networks and not on the same networks I think you should put the advertised host and port for each P2P service
Yes, in my instance I am specifying my external IP with the --p2p-host flag. I'm not sure that it's making much difference though, from yehia67's case.

> Yes, I tried both ways, UPNP and MANUAL for nat-method. I will try leaving it runnng longer and report back :)
> 
> Yes, I sanitized the logs, to indicate internal LAN versus external IP, there. I'm not specifying the network, so Im just trying to connect to MAINNET, the default setting there.

Yes it may take time before finding peers. Feel free to tell us if that doesn't solve the issue

Hi there. I have let it run for 20+ minutes trying both UPNP and MANUAL nat-methods. No luck, still just says no sync target.

Let me know if there's anything else I can try or more logs I might be able to generate to help debug this issue and connect to the other validators. Thanks again

> Hi there. I have let it run for 20+ minutes trying both UPNP and MANUAL nat-methods. No luck, still just says no sync target.
> 
> Let me know if there's anything else I can try or more logs I might be able to generate to help debug this issue and connect to the other validators. Thanks again

Could you send me the command line you use to launch besu? Did you do your last tests on the mainnet or in a private network?

I see that your are trying to configure a network of static nodes.  Do you set `--discovery-enabled` to `false` as specified in the documentation?
https://besu.hyperledger.org/en/stable/HowTo/Find-and-Connect/Static-Nodes/#configure-static-nodes

@joshuafernandes  okay thank you.

-  Does GBA have a seperate bootnodes list or do they use their validators as bootnodes too?

Currently, we are using validators as bootnodes.  This will change as we get more nodes.

-     Does GBA enforce any permissions scheme on nodes joining in? Or is the enode that you provide purely to serve as a validator?

We do not enforce any permissions scheme.

-     Do they allow connections from outside of Azure ie. do they run any vpn routes for new nodes as part of the setup via their GUI?

We do not run any vpn routes.

This may be required, we're still learning.

@joshuafernandes Can you give me some instructions for connecting to a public Besu Ethereum testnet or mainnet, for me to test? Do those nodes run on Azure, and do they run any VPN connection that allows the outside world to connect?

Can you give us instructions for how a VPN tunnel would typically be set up for a Besu network running on Azure to allow outside validator / non-validator node connections?

Hi @Tectract apologies for the delay in getting back to you - been extremely busy.

Based on @MWaser replies, the first thing I would do is ensure you can communicate with the bootnodes in GBA from where your nodes are:

Ensure your firewall has 30303 open for TCP & UDP traffic.

Check for udp connectivity:
`nc -vu GBA_bootnode_ip 30303` 

Check for tcp connectivity:
`nc -vt GBA_bootnode_ip 30303` 

If both return successful connections then you should have no issues connection to the best of my knowledge. The VPN tunnel is the next step in the event that you do not have direct connectivity into GBA ie. its private inside Azure only. There are a few ways to do this, basically it just needs to know how to route to a given CIDR block (the ones in Azure). Azure's recommendations for a VPN https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/vpn-gateway/vpn-gateway-howto-site-to-site-resource-manager-portal 

We dont run a testnet in Azure, but we've got a template that you can use to create an IBFT2 network in Azure here: https://github.com/PegaSysEng/besu-terraform/tree/master/azure/ibft-4-validators. You'll need to make a couple of changes to get this going to make this public:
- change all of the source_address_prefix values to "*" for the discovery ports security rules in the eth_nsg (lines 238 & 227) in https://github.com/PegaSysEng/besu-terraform/blob/master/azure/ibft-4-validators/main.tf#L170

Once thats up, you should see blocks being created and then run the same `nc` tests from above. I expect that they should return successful and you should be able to connect Besu to them. As before, when you fire up Besu please use an externally accessible IP - ie the nodes in Azure must also be able to talk to your nodes on 30303 UDP & TCP.

As a foot note, to connect to mainnet or one of the other test networks, I dont know of a specific node in Azure but each public network has preconfigured bootnodes in Besu so you could add a `--network=ropsten` [option](https://besu.hyperledger.org/en/stable/Reference/CLI/CLI-Syntax/#network) when firing up Besu and remove any bootnode parameters. The other option stay the same 

Let us know how you go

Cheers

> nc -vt ethxxxxxxxxxxx.eastus2.cloudapp.azure.com 30303

Should I refer them to this?

> There are a few ways to do this, basically it just needs to know how to route to a given CIDR block (the ones in Azure). Azure's recommendations for a VPN https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/vpn-gateway/vpn-gateway-howto-site-to-site-resource-manager-portal

Hi @Tectract 

Yep, Im not sure how they've got Besu configured on their end. Basically the network security group needs 30303 open for TCP and UDP and then it should just work. This is the link in the docs explaining that without it open for TCP no nodes can communicate
https://besu.hyperledger.org/en/stable/HowTo/Find-and-Connect/Configuring-Ports/#p2p-networking

Cheers
Josh
@Tectract I'll close this issue for now, but please re-open if there is anything else.

I'd like you to know that the GBA essentially gave up trying to start their blockchain using the Azure cloud. Nobody noticed that little note about how it will not work at all unless you make special network rules allowing TCP traffic on port 30303, and even when I mentioned that's what they needed to do, they still couldn't figure out how to do it. So, we never resolved this issue. GBA was unable to launch their blockchain on Azure using Bezu node, essentially.

I would like to suggest that TCP be opened on port 30303 by default from now on unless there is some reason that can't be done by default. Having it closed cost us a ton of time and basically prevented us from being able to launch a blockchain on Azure.
Thanks for the feedback @Tectract, I'll check in with the team about having it open by default.
